docs.lead_paragraph: Many people, who have in fact lost weight, remain convinced that they look fat. OSING WEIGHT can be difficult, but adjusting to a new, thinner self can be even more so. After weight loss, many people do not know what their bodies really look like. They remain haunted by the thought that they still look and feel fat - no matter how many successful readings by scale and tape measure. Added to this is anxiety over the life changes that thinness can bring. In short, the mind can sabotage the body, a potential concern, experts say, for many of the 80 million overweight Americans. ''A major obstacle to losing weight and then staying thin is a 'fat head,' '' say the diet authors Dr. Maria Simonson and Joan Rattner Heilman. ''A thin person with a fat head is someone who always feels fat, regardless of how much he or she really weighs.''
